ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

BASIC FOODSTUFFS
(Compilation of price-list)


    1. Inche Abdul Aziz Karim asked the Minister of Finance whether the Department of Statistic will compile a list of prices of basic foodstuffs in the main markets in Singapore and make such information available to the public

Column: 830

daily through radio television and the press to keep the people informed of price trends so that they may avoid being overcharged by unscrupulous vendors.

Column: 831



    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance (Mr Tang See Chim) (for the Minister for Finance): Mr Speaker, Sir, at present, retail prices for a wide range of basic foodstuffs, perishable and non-perishable, are collected regularly by the Department of Statistics for the purpose of the compilation of the Consumer Price Index. The items included for regular pricing were selected based on a Household Expenditure Survey conducted by the Statistics Department and generally reflect the consumption pattern of the average household. For perishable foodstuffs, e.g., meat, poultry, fish, fruits and vegetables, prices are collected weekly from market-stalls in eight markets in the Republic. In the case of non-perishable foodstuffs where the prices are normally not subject to frequent daily fluctuations, e.g., rice and sundry provisions, prices are collected twice a month from retail shops distributed in the main shopping centres. A total of about 140 items are covered in this regular price collection, and the data are primarily used for the compilation of the Consumer Price Index. Monthly average prices of the major items are also compiled and published in the Monthly Digest of Statistics. Occasional revisions to the list of items have been made as and when necessary, and the Department intends to undertake a detailed study of the existing retail price collection system and the compilation of the Consumer Price Index with a view to assessing the need for any major changes.

    The data collected for the compilation of the retail price index are not suitable for use as a daily guide to the consuming public for the following reasons:

    (1) the data are not collected daily;

    (2) prices tend to vary according to locality, from market to market and in different stalls in the same market;

    (3) prices depend on the quality of items, the buyer/seller relationship and the bargaining capacity of the customer.

Column: 832



    The retail price index is a weighted average of prices of goods and services entering into the consumption pattern of the average working-class household. In compiling the index, specific care is taken to exclude the influence on prices arising from the variations in locality, quality of product, buyer/seller relationship and the bargaining capacity of customers, which are important factors directly affecting the personal shopper in the market.

    These considerations will still obtain even if the data are collected daily and will therefore not provide the kind of guidance to the consuming public that the Member for Kallang would desire.

    In view of this and of the expenses that would be involved in a daily collection of data, it is considered uneconomical to employ a large number of staff and resources to undertake such an exercise.

HOUSE ASSESSMENTS
(Disparity)


    2. Mr N. Govindasamy asked the Minister for Finance why is the annual value of certain dwelling houses in a housing estate assessed at double that of other houses in the same estate where the houses are each of similar construction and size and owner-occupied.

    Mr Tang See Chim (for the Minister for Finance): Mr Speaker, Sir, every property on the Valuation List should be valued in the same manner. From time to time, the Chief Assessor corrects the Valuation List to remove anomalies which are brought to his attention. Due to the considerable workload in the department, it has not been possible to correct all the anomalies that arose from earlier valuations by the City Council and the Rural Board.

    There are instances where values shown on the Valuation List have to be corrected for individual houses in the same area, but care is taken to ensure that the property tax payable is the same.

Column: 833



    If the Member for Telok Blangah will write to me on specific cases that he comes across, I will see to it that the anomalies are corrected.

    Mr N. Govindasamy (Telok Blangah): Sir, it is not a matter of old houses being valued at City Council rates, but a matter of houses in the same estate being valued at different rates and certain houses being given concessions -

    Mr Speaker: Mr Govindasamy, we have 26 questions on the Order Paper and I think you had better accept the Parliamentary Secretary's invitation to write to him than embark on a speech at this time.

Column: 833

STAMP OFFICE
(Measures to speed up work)


    3. Mr Hwang Soo Jin asked the Minister for Finance what measures have been taken or are being taken to speed up the work at the Stamp Office in order to cope with the increased pressure on that Department as a direct result of the recent amendment to the Stamp Ordinance.

    Mr Tang See Chim (for the Minister for Finance): Mr Speaker, Sir, the recent amendments to the Stamp Ordinance only alter the rates of stamp duties payable on documents. These amendments should not increase the workload on the Stamp Office, once the rates are gotten used to. There is therefore no permanent increased pressure on the Stamp Office as a direct result of the amendments to the Stamp Ordinance. In December, however, there was a rush to stamp documents before the increased duties came into force in January 1969. But that was a temporary pressure which has eased off.

    However, hon. Members may be happy to hear that shortly after the coming into force of the amending Act, the Organisation and Methods Branch of the Ministry of Finance was asked to make a study of the system at the Stamp Office with a view to increasing its efficiency and to giving the public

Column: 834

better service. As a result of this study, it has been decided to provide three more Assistant Examiners for the Stamp Office and to install two more franking machines. This should further improve the services at the Stamp Office.

    Arrangements are also in hand for more documents to be stamped by franking machines, so that these docu ments do not have to be brought to the Stamp Office, thereby reducing the workload at the counter.

Column: 834

TRADE DESCRIPTIONS ACT, 1968, OF UNITED KINGDOM
(Introduction of similar legislation in Singapore)


    4. Mr P. Selvadurai asked the Minister for Finance if he will consider introducing legislation similar to the Trade Descriptions Act, 1968, of the United Kingdom.

    Mr Tang See Chim (for the Minister for Finance): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Government has made a study of the United Kingdom Trade Descriptions Act. 1968, and feels there is no immediate need to introduce similar legislation in Singapore. General principles embodied in the United Kingdom Act, particularly those provisions prohibiting misdescription or counterfeiting of goods, are already covered by the following Singapore Ordinances:

    (1) Trade Marks Ordinance;

    (2) Merchandise Marks Ordinance; and

    (3) Sale of Food and Drugs Ordinance.

    As far as the new provisions are concerned, such as false or misleading indications as to the price of goods and the power given to United Kingdom officials to impose requirements in the description of goods in advertisements, and the power to assign meanings to certain expressions, it is considered too early at present to decide whether to incorporate them into our law, since our existing laws are working fairly efficiently and are adequate to deal with

Column: 835

the situation. The Government would therefore prefer to wait and see how the new legislation works out in the United Kingdom so that if we eventually decide to incorporate the new provisions into our own law, we would have the benefit of their experience.

Column: 835

IRON AND STEEL MILL


    5. Mr Lee Teck Him asked the Minister for Finance if he will encourage the setting up of another iron and steel mill in Singapore.

    The Minister for Finance (Dr Goh Keng Swee): Mr Speaker, Sir, the answer is "No". There is no advantage to Singapore in a proliferation of steel mills. It will not increase employment or output. It will mean the sharing of a fixed domestic market by more producers, and will probably result in excess capacity. Most of our steel products are produced by National Iron and Steel Mills Ltd., in which Government has a significant equity holding. Prices of products as well as prices of scrap are controlled by Government, to ensure that customers and scrap dealers have a fair deal. More than 30 per cent of the output is exported and most of the profits of the Company are not distributed to shareholders but are ploughed back to the industry for further expansion, so as to create more jobs for Singapore citizens.

    Mr Lee Teck Him (Ulu Pandan)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, in my view, one iron and steel mill is not good enough, because our country is in the process of development, and consumption of iron and steel is very high. For this reason, we should have a quota system. We should have a few iron and steel mills in Singapore. I have heard people saying that -

    Mr Speaker: Order. Mr Lee, you heard what I told Mr Govindasamy just now. I cannot allow a speech at this stage. Do you have a supplementary question?

Column: 836



    Mr Lee Teck Him: No, Sir.

RADIO AND TELEVISION LICENCES
(Non-receipt of renewal forms)


    6. Mr Yeoh Ghim Seng asked the Minister for Finance if he will instruct officers of the Radio and Television Licensing Section to investigate com plaints of the non-receipt of renewal forms by radio and television licence-holders; and if he will instruct those officers not to institute prosecutions in cases where the complaint is well founded and the licence-holder renews his licence at the first opportunity after expiry.

    Mr Tang See Chim (for the Minister for Finance): Mr Speaker, Sir, the non-receipt of renewal forms by radio and television licence-holders has been in vestigated. Over 17,000 licences are renewed each month, and the number of reports of non-receipt of renewal forms is about 200 or 3 per cent.

    Generally, the non-receipt of renewal forms is through the failure of the licensees to inform the Department of their change of address. Failure to notify change of address is in itself an offence but so far no one has been prosecuted.

    Where a licence-holder gives reasonable grounds for failure to renew his licence, no prosecution is instituted.

    A licence may be renewed one month before the valid licence expires.

Column: 836

GOVERNMENT QUARTERS
(Replacement of old quarters by multi-storey flats)


    7. Mr Tay Boon Too asked the Minister for Finance if he is aware that some Government quarters, for example, those in the Haig Road and Farrer Park areas, are old and are rented out to civil servants at uneconomic rents, and if he will consider pulling down such quarters and erecting multi-storey flats instead, so that more families of civil servants can be accommodated and more rents collected.

Column: 837



    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Mr Speaker, Sir, the provision of quarters for civil servants is a colonial practice which we have inherited and have been unable to terminate because this involves a reduction of perquisites enjoyed by occupiers of these quarters. It seems to be an enshrined principle that no civil servant shall have his conditions of service made worse off in any circumstances, though I cannot find any authority either in law or in the Constitution for this principle. Governments of modern states do not provide quarters at low rents to government employees except in special cases, such as military camps, lighthouses and so on. We should move slowly towards this position and are, in fact, doing so. When occupiers of quarters retire, or resign or are dismissed, it is the intention not to rent out these quarters to other employees but rent them out to the public at economic rents. Civil servants should be encouraged to own their own houses, and more and more of them are in fact doing so. I agree that some of the more ancient quarters could with advantage be pulled down to make way for high-rise flats. Their occupants can be moved to comfortable Housing Board flats. This is true not only for quarters in Haig Road and Farrer Park but also elsewhere.

    Mr Ho See Beng (Bras Basah): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Minister for Finance says that the provision of quarters to civil servants by the colonial Government was a bad practice. Will the Minister agree with me that the P.A.P., a socialist Government, should adopt a good practice?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Yes, Sir.

Column: 837

NATIONAL DEFENCE TAX ON
CAPITAL INVESTMENTS


    8. Mr Lee Teck Him asked the Minister for Finance whether he will consider the levy of a national defence tax on capital investments by Singapore Citizens in commercial and industrial undertakings on the following scale:-

Column: 838



    (a) 1 per cent of investment between $100,000 and $500,000;

    (b) 2 per cent of investment between $500,000 and $1,000,000;

    (c) 3 per cent of investment between $1,000,000 and $5,000,000;

    (d) 5 per cent of investment between $5,000,000 and above;

and if he will introduce the necessary legislation.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Sir, I see no merit whatsoever in the hon. Member's proposal. At the present moment, we want to increase the rate of investment so as to increase our economic growth. With economic growth, tax yields increase, thereby producing the additional money for defence. The hon. Member wants to penalise citizens who invest in Singapore. Incidentally, does he propose to exempt foreign investors from this tax? lf not, why not? He should not be surprised, in the event the P.A.P. Government were mad enough to accept his proposal, that the Government ends up with less total revenue instead of more. It may be comforting to the hon. Member to know that his ideas are not really unique and several developing countries had been pursuing policies of this kind. The rich and successful are targets of envy, more especially so if they belong to an ethnic minority. Action is taken to deprive them of their wealth, or that part of it the Government can lay their hands on. The end result is not progress and better living standards for the masses, but economic ruin and increasing poverty for everyone.

    Mr Lee Teck Him(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Minister for Finance says that my proposal has no merit. I think he is mistaken. The advantage of my proposal is that we would be able to buy aeroplanes. Right now the money in the National Defence Fund is not sufficient to buy even one aeroplane. What can we do? Of course, we have to aim at the rich.

Column: 839



    The Minister for Finance also says that investors would be discouraged from investing in Singapore. Actually I am aiming at Singapore citizens. On an investment of $100,000, they should be taxed $1,000. On $1 million, they should be taxed $30,000.

    Mr Speaker: Mr Lee, I take it that your supplementary question is, has the Minister for Finance considered alternative means of raising money that will be raised by this device?

    Mr Lee Teck Him(In Mandarin): What I want is to reply to him.

    Mr Speaker: Standing Orders do not permit you to reply. Please frame a supplementary question.

    Mr Lee Teck Him(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, my point is this. We need to build up our national defence. To achieve this, we need to aim at the rich. We should not aim at the poor by increasing the tax on P.U.B. bills. This is making the burden heavier on the poor. What we should do is to aim at the rich.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Sir, these matters have been dealt with by me at great length and in great detail in my Budget speech. May I invite the hon. Member to make some research in this direction? If he does, I am sure he will not find grounds for saying that we are taxing the poor. It has already been made clear in my Budget speech that exemption limits have been imposed whereby the poorest people are exempt from paying a tax on P.U.B, bills. More than half of the customers of the P.U.B, do not pay such additional tax. I do not know why the hon. Member still persists in believing what the Barisan Sosialis have been saying in Singapore.

    Mr Lee Teck Him(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, if the Minister for Finance says that the P.U.B, tax is not aimed at the poor, I am prepared to withdraw my question.

RETRENCHED WORKERS
(Figures)


    9. Mr Eric Cheong Yuen Chee asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Minister for Labour what is the number of workers retrenched during each of the years 1966 to 1968, and what is the percentage of these numbers in the private sector.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Labour (Mr Sia Kah Hui) (for the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Minister for Labour): Mr Speaker, Sir, the British Armed Forces commenced their retrenchment exercise sometime in mid 1967, and during that year declared 479 civilian employees redundant. In 1968, 4,340 civilian employees were declared redundant, of whom 3.293 ex-employees of the British Navy were employed by the Government-owned Sembawang Shipyard as from 1st December, 1968.

    In the private sector the number of workers retrenched during each of the years 1966 to 1968 is as follows:

    In 1966 there were six firms involved and 94 workers were retrenched.

    In 1967 there were 13 firms involved and 322 workers were retrenched.

    In 1968 there were 11 firms involved and 390 workers were retrenched. Based on the figures available in the Ministry of Labour, the total number of workers retrenched in 1966 was 94, all of whom were employed in the private sector. In 1967 a total of 801 workers were retrenched, of whom about 40 per cent were from the private sector. In 1968 a total of 4,730 workers were retrenched, of whom only about eight per cent came from the private sector.

Column: 840

RETRENCHED WORKERS IN
PRIVATE SECTOR
(Retraining schemes)


    10. Mr Eric Cheong Yuen Chee asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Minister for Labour whether the Government proposes to provide a

Column: 841

retraining scheme for retrenched workers in the private sector similar to that offered to retrenched workers of the British military establishments.

    Mr Sia Kah Hui (for the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Minister for Labour): Sir, the magnitude of the redundancy problem affecting some 30,000 civilian employees in the British Armed Forces has made it imperative to organise a retraining scheme for these workers to fit them for alternative employment. This does not necessarily mean that all employees declared redundant can be retrained. The limited resources of the Technical Education Department are at the moment fully taken up in this task. It must be pointed out that the cost of training is high and, therefore, it is the intention of the Government to recover the training cost from the British Government under the special aid scheme.

    The Government does not propose to provide a retraining scheme for retrenched workers in the private sector because the number involved is very small. Further, a retraining scheme for retrenched workers in the private sector would call for the provision of substantial funds. This being so, it may well be necessary for training costs to be paid by the workers themselves. The hon. Member will appreciate that, taking the circumstances as a whole, there is no urgent need for a retraining scheme for retrenched workers in the private sector at the moment.

Column: 841

RETRENCHED WORKERS
(Estimated cost of retraining schemes)


    11. Mr Eric Cheong Yuen Chee asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Minister for Labour what is the estimated cost for organising the retraining scheme for retrenched workers of the British military establishments; and what will be the estimated cost for providing similar facilities to retrenched workers in the private sector.

    Mr Sia Kah Hui (for the Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Minister for Labour): Sir, based on the experience

Column: 842

of the first course organised for ietrenched base workers, the total cost of retraining 561 workers would be in the region of $57,000, which would include instruction fees, cost of materials and overhead. On this basis, the estimated cost of training each worker for a period of three months would be about $100.

    If a retraining scheme were organised for retrenched workers in the private sector, the cost would probably be no different. Indeed, costs can be influenced by the type of training to be given. For example, if electric welding were to be taught, the cost of materials and electricity would be much higher. The hon. Member will appreciate that in the light of the answers I have given to his other questions, there appears to be no justification at the moment to incur such costs.

    Mr Eric Cheong Yuen Chee (Toa Payoh): If the unions concerned are prepared to foot the bill, will the Minister consider operating such a scheme for retrenched workers in the private sector in conjunction with that accorded to service personnel?

    Mr Sia Kah Hui: Sir, I do not think it is just a question of costs involved. We will still have to look for space and instructors, and there are so many other factors affecting such courses. If the unions concerned are interested in any particular retraining scheme, I shall be very glad to have some idea of it on paper. We can then give the matter serious consideration.

Column: 842

SINGAPORE CITIZENSHIP FOR
FOREIGNERS UNDER
5-YEAR RULE
(Particulars)


    12. Mr P. Selvadurai asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Minister for Labour (a) what is the number of foreigners who have been granted Singapore citizenship under the 5-year rule; (b) how many of them are employed by the Government and

Column: 843

statutory bodies; (c) how many such persons have left the service of the Government or statutory bodies; and (d) what were the criteria adopted in granting Singapore citizenship under the 5-year rule.

    Mr Sia Kah Hui (for the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Minister for Labour): Sir, the number of foreigners who have been granted Singapore citizenship under the 5-year rule is 65. Forty-three of them are employed by the Government and statutory bodies. Two such persons have left the service of the Government. The criteria adopted in granting Singapore citizenship under the 5-year rule were announced in May 1967. Briefly they are as follows.

    First, persons who invest a minimum of $250,000 in any industry in the Republic are given permanent residence by the Immigration Department. They are eligible to apply for citizenship under the 5-year criteria but citizenship is not automatically given to them.

    Secondly, senior civil servants and officers of statutory boards.

    Thirdly, persons possessing technical or managerial skills whom the Economic Development Board would like to attract to Singapore.

    Lastly, other persons who have made outstanding contributions to the progress and welfare of the Republic.

    Mr Ho See Beng: Is the idea of allowing a foreigner to invest $250,000 in Singapore so that he can come here and become a permanent resident an original idea of the P.A.P. Government, or is it copied from other countries in the world?

    Mr Sia Kah Hui: Sir, I think it makes no difference whether we copy it or not so long as the objective is a good one. I think the hon. Member will agree that whatever is good any socialist government will adopt. Never mind where it comes from.

Column: 844

SENIOR CAMBRIDGE
EXAMINATION
(Replacement by local examination)


    13. Mr Lee Teck Him asked the Minister for Education whether and when the Senior Cambridge Examination will be replaced by an examination to be conducted by a local examination board.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Education (Dr Lee Chiaw Meng) (for the Minister for Education)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I remember during the budget debate for the current financial year, the hon. Member for Ulu Pandan raised the same question. Our answer remains the same. At the present moment, we have no intention to replace the Cambridge School Certificate Examination by a local examination because so far this examination can satisfy the requirements of Singapore in respect of examination of pupils in the English stream. However, in view of our bilingual education policy and the present emphasis on technical education, discussions are being held with the Cambridge Syndicate with a view to making such modifications and adjustments as are necessary to meet our new requirements.

    Mr Lee Teck Him rose -

    Mr Speaker: Mr Lee, may I remind you of my earlier remark that you should ask a supplementary question and not make a speech?
